docs.lead_paragraph: FEW parents ever dream of their daughter marrying a puppeteer. It is not exactly a profession that yells money or security. An early retirement in Florida doesn't leap to mind. Nor does health insurance. Nearly three years ago, Susan Elia, a freelance dance writer, broke the news to her mother: she was dating a professional puppeteer named Noel MacNeal. ''My mother's reaction was, 'O.K., what does he really do?' '' Ms. Elia remembered. '' 'What does he do for money?' She had an image of a nerdy guy doing birthday parties.''
docs.abstract: Vows column on wedding of Susan Elia and Noel MacNeal; photos (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: HIS name may not be familiar to anyone but his own employees, but chances are you've heard about what Al Galdi has done: given new BMW's to any employee who has worked at his company for at least a year. During the last six months, Mr. Galdi has handed out BMW keys to 34 of his 45 employees. The cars, which are leased, cost him about $9,000 a year each, including insurance. Needless to say, turnover at Arcnet, an architectural engineering firm in Holmdel, N.J., has been virtually nil since Mr. Galdi began offering the perk in June. Employees who leave have to give back the cars.

headline.main: Better Perks Resonate in Boom Times

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN President Clinton signed legislation on Friday updating the Depression-era law governing banking, insurance and Wall Street, he was doing little more than allowing Washington to catch up with the sweeping changes that have reshaped the financial services industry over the past few decades. In Congress, the two parties have yet to really address the public outcry over the health care industry's drive to cut costs. While they dithered, the landscape was abruptly altered again last week when one of the nation's largest managed care companies reversed the trend by returning power over treatment choices to doctors.
docs.abstract: Government faces growing challenge in keeping pace with what is happening on front lines of business in an economy that changes as swiftly as American economy, driven in particular by breathtaking technological advances; securities regulators are struggling to keep up with rapid growth of on-line stock trading; no one in Washington seems to know quite how to protect consumers against unauthorized use of data about everything from their medical histories to their supermarket purchases; nowhere is issue playing out more vividly--or with higher stakes--than in Justice Department's antitrust case against Microsoft Corp; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Six Fairfield University students and a professor ended a hunger strike yesterday after the institution announced it would drop a contracting company that the students said was anti-union and paid janitors poorly. The students applauded the university's move, saying their hunger strike brought about the change. But university officials insisted that the hunger strike had no effect on their decision to drop the contractor.

headline.main: Six Students End Hunger Strike After Fairfield Drops Contractor

docs.lead_paragraph: EDWARD M. KENNEDY A Biography By Adam Clymer Illustrated. 692 pages. William Morrow & Company. $27.50. In 1968, after Robert Kennedy's assassination had deprived the nation of his likely election to the presidency, Democratic Party leaders urged his 36-year-old brother, Senator Ted Kennedy, to run in his place. They assured him that the nomination was his for the asking. Senator Kennedy refused: ''How could I conscientiously combat allegations by Nixon . . . that I was too young, that I had no record in public life strong enough to recommend me for the high office of president, that perhaps I was trying to trade on my brothers' names.''

headline.main: The Public Servant Behind the Public Kennedy

docs.lead_paragraph: Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital and Aetna U. S. Healthcare said yesterday that the hospital would treat the health plan's members until April 30. Marla Diamond, a spokesman for Robert Wood Johnson, in New Brunswick, N.J., said that because of confusion among members over when services would end and because of the many telephone inquiries the hospital had received, the hospital and the insurer had decided to end service for all members on April 30.

headline.main: Metro Business; Hospital and H.M.O. Agree on Cutoff Date

docs.lead_paragraph: Fearful that Japan's tenuous recovery from its worst postwar recession could collapse in an election year, the government announced a package of economic stimulants today worth 18 trillion yen, or about $171.4 billion, almost twice the amount that had been expected just a few weeks ago. The package, which includes a vastly expanded loan program for small businesses and a large increase in spending on bridges, roads and other public work projects represents the ninth huge government infusion of money into the economy since Japan tumbled into a severe slump seven years ago. There is no guarantee that it is the last package.

headline.main: Japan Moves To Stimulate Its Economy

docs.abstract: Japanese government announces package of economic stimulants worth 18 trillion yen, or about $171.4 billion, almost twice amount that had been expected a few weeks ago; package, which includes vastly expanded loan program for small businesses and large increase in public works projects represents ninth huge government infusion of money into economy since Japan went into severe slump seven years ago; Prime Miin Keizo Obuchi, who must call elections by next September, is suffering in polls; he cannot afford to risk return to near-stagnation; plan is not expected to stimulate further consumer demand; many big Japanese companies are in process of revamping operations and reducing employment, and consumers are afraid to spend when they fear lower wages and possible joblessness (M)
